userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: Some materials in these collections may be protected by the U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.). In addition, the reproduction of some materials may be restricted by terms of University of California gift or purchase agreements, donor restrictions, privacy and publicity rights, licensing and trademarks. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by copyright beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owner. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user. All requests to reproduce, publish, quote from, or otherwise use collection materials must be submitted to The Bancroft Library. See: http://bancroft.berkeley.edu/reference/permissions.html .

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged thematically in 8 series: Series 1: Vertical Files; Series 2: Humboldt County Photographic Survey; Series 3: Albums (boxed); Series 4: Postcards; Series 5: Save the Redwoods League Officers; Series 6: Photographer Files; Series 7: Miscellaneous Negatives and Lantern Slides; Series 8: Miscellany.

bioghist.p: The Save the Redwoods League is a non-profit organization, established in 1918, whose mission "is to protect and restore redwood forests and connect people with their peace and beauty so these wonders of the natural world flourish." (from Save the Redwoods League website, 2016.)

scopecontent.p: This collection chiefly consists of photographs (approximately 9,700 photographic prints, 5,400 negatives, and 1,000 slides) of redwood trees, forests and parks in coastal Northern California, as well as giant sequoia trees in the Sierra Nevada area, taken by, taken for, or collected by, Save the Redwoods League staff and members to support its mission. There is additional pictorial material relating to the League itself. Of note are images of League official and National Parks Director Newton B. Drury, photographs of California Governors Edmund G. Brown and Ronald Reagan, U.S. Presidents Herbert Hoover, Lyndon B. Johnson and Bill Clinton, First Lady Lady Bird Johnson, logging, grove dedications, Dawn Redwood at Mo-tao-chi in Central China, and highway and erosion studies in Northern California redwood country. Also includes posters that relate the age of redwood trees to events in history, and panoramic photographs.

Folders contain photographs (or prints of digital images) unless noted. Other material includes postcards, prints, posters, drawings, brochure and pamphlet samples, some documents, newsclippings, ceremonial pens and plaques.

physdesc.extent: cartons 1-8; A box 1; AX box 1, folders 1-20; B box 1, folders 1-15, 17-18; C box 1; D folder 1; F folder 1; H folder 1; NEG boxes 1-5; NEG(gl) boxes 1, 3, 8, 9; NNEG boxes 1-6

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: Subject file that consists chiefly of material removed from file cabinets of Save the Redwoods League offices. The bulk of the material is photographic prints that range from snapshots taken by staff members to 8x10 prints and panoramas taken by professional photographers. Other kinds of non-photographic material included, such as posters, documents and newsclippings, are noted in the folder content notes.

The bulk of the subjects include state parks, state recreation areas, and national parks, landscapes of redwood forests and watersheds, logging, scenic highways through the areas, dedication ceremonies, and visitors to the parks. There are also images related to the Save the Redwoods League organization and its leaders.

Most locations are in California, especially Northern California. Major parks include Big Basin Redwoods State Park, Calaveras Big Trees State Park, Del Norte Coast Redwoods State Park, Humboldt Redwoods State Park, Jedediah Smith Redwoods State Park, Prairie Creek Redwoods State Park, Redwood National Park, and Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks.

odd.p: Original alphabetical arrangement and folder heading descriptions from the file cabinet folders have largely been retained. Some folder headings have been changed by Bancroft Library staff for consistency, and to keep like subjects together. Some material not originally found in the vertical files, such as thin notebook type albums, have been filed here by Bancroft Library staff for researcher convenience. Oversize materials are described in this series as well. Subjects listed are 1 folder, unless otherwise noted.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: Photographic survey of land in Humboldt County, mainly along U.S. Highway 101 (Redwood Highway) corridor, moving from south to north. The bulk of images are of redwood groves, especially in and around Humboldt Redwoods State Park. Includes views of the Eel River, South Fork of Eel River, coastal areas, and a few views in Mendocino County.

odd.p: The photographs are identified by a rough number scheme assigned by Save the Redwoods League, from 1 to 12100s. Lower numbers are in the southern part of Humboldt County, and the higher numbers are in the northern part of the county. Numbering schemes 12000s to13000s are subject oriented. Eel River and South Fork of Eel River folders are surveys of the rivers, but the photographs are unnumbered. Some unnumbered, but related photographs were found interfiled with numbered photographs.

The material arrived at the Bancroft Library either in the form of an album, or foldered loose photographs. Many albums were disbound, and photos removed from pages by Save the Redwoods League. Album pages and loose photographs were foldered together with related photographs and negatives. Albums that arrived at the Bancroft library intact were disbound and foldered by library staff for easier use and conservation purposes.

The loose photographs are a combination of intact album pages, photographs removed from album pages, and related photographs. Many items are duplicates of images in the albums, and follow the same numbering system as the albums. Many of the original folders these loose items were housed in were identified as, "Project I. Humboldt Redwoods."
NITRATE NEGATIVES (NNEG boxes): CLOSED TO RESEARCH DUE TO HAZARDOUS MATERIALS RESTRICTIONS.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: Albums created or collected by Save-the-Redwoods League staff. The bulk of the albums are related to a theme, from trips documenting various redwood forest locations and areas of proposed land acquisition, to tributes and League events. Of note is a study on problems of U.S. Highway 101 widening and re-alignment.

odd.p: Thin notebook type albums that were boxed together by Save the Redwoods League staff have been moved to the Vertical Files, and filed by subject.

Two automobiles on a road through a redwood forest.

scopecontent.p: Redwood grove and river views in Northern California. Includes Russ Grove, Felton Grove, Bolling Grove, Richardson's Grove, Stephen's Grove, Phillipsville Grove, Eel River, Klamath River, Stone Lagoon, whaling station at Trinidad, James Irvine Tree, road near Scotia, Lane's auto park, bridge at Fernbridge Station, and bridge at Garberville. One loose photo print by Freeman Art Co. of Bolling Grove in front of album.

did.unittitle: Views of State Highway U.S. 101 Humboldt Redwoods State Park Illustrating Problems in Highway Widening and Re-Alignment (volumes 1- 3).

scopecontent.p: Three albums prepared by California State Parks Commission, with cooperation of United States Department of Interior, National Park Service. Includes maps showing locations of views.
Volume 1: photos 1-34
Volume 2: photos 35- 77
Volume 3: photos 78-110

odd.p: Volumes were received by the Bancroft Library in the form of spiral notebooks. Library staff disbound the notebooks and foldered the pages for conservation purposes. Duplicate volumes contain a few different images. Duplicate of volume 1 includes additional loose photographs.
1 matching negative from volume 1, page 27 removed to NNEG box 3 (with Humboldt Redwoods State Park -- Highway Survey negatives.)

did.unittitle: Save the Redwoods League Acquisitions Program for Four Northern Projects.

scopecontent.p: Black and white and color photographs by Howard King, Moulin Studios, David Swanlund, Doug Yule of four state parks in Northern California.
1. Humboldt Redwoods State Park. Includes Bull Creek watershed, Pepperwood Flat, Avenue of the Giants, California Federation of Women's Clubs Grove and Eel River.
2. Prairie Creek Redwoods State Park. Includes Fern Canyon, Gold Bluffs Beach, Prairie Creek, Redwood Creek, National Council of State Garden Clubs Grove and Willits Grove.
3. Del Norte Coast Redwoods. Includes Del Norte Coast and rhododendron.
4. Jedediah Smith State Park. Includes former Simpson Timber Company land, Mill Creek, Howland Hill Road, Old Stage Coach Road, Metcalf Grove and Stout Tree.
Photographs by Martin Litton of ground level and aerial views of redwood forests, and land after logging clear cut, divided into four regions:
1. Redwood Creek watershed area, which includes Arcata Redwood Company land
2. Little Lost Man Creek watershed area, which includes C. Thomas land and Berry Glen cut.
3. Prairie Creek Redwoods State Park area, which includes clear cut logging on Arcata Redwood Company land, Gold Bluffs Road and freeway construction.

4. Jedediah Smith Redwoods State Park area, which includes adopted freeway route (US 199) through the park, Mill Creek Road, Smith River, Simpson Reed Grove, National Tribute Grove, east portal of Ridge Tunnel and clear cut of Malarkey Forest.

odd.p: Duplicates photos can be found in the Vertical Files under the subject.
Matching negatives in NEG box 5.

scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous film negatives that are unidentified, or have questionable identification, and are lacking prints. Bulk are landscapes, especially with redwood trees, and are probably in Humboldt County, California.

odd.p: The majority of these negatives were received from Save-the-Redwoods League foldered amongst the Humboldt County Photographic Survey photographs.
NITRATE NEGATIVES (NNEG boxes): CLOSED TO RESEARCH DUE TO HAZARDOUS MATERIALS RESTRICTIONS.

scopecontent.p: Redwood groves and picnic areas.

odd.p: Negatives from envelope removed from Newton B. Drury correspondence files, 1920s-1980s.

scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous subjects, the bulk of which are landscapes with redwood trees. Most locations are probably Humboldt County or Northern California. Includes coastal views; rivers, some which could be South Fork of the Eel River; dirt and paved roads, some which could be the Redwood Highway; tree stumps; cabins; people standing by redwood trees; baby in a basket; "Hays prop." Some negatives dated April1931, and could be related to Hartsook's and Gillogly, Humboldt County, negatives of the same date.

Various landscapes, most which are probably in Humboldt County or Northern California. Some could be Lane Grove/Fish Creek area. Includes redwood trees; rivers, some which could be South Fork of the Eel River; dirt and paved roads, some which could be the Redwood Highway; clear-cut or fire damaged areas; coastal views; meadows; pastures; buildings in rural areas and cabins; people next to cross section of trees; Joshua trees; "The Little Red Hen"; "Plummer".

odd.p: One negative from envelope labeled: Blackburn negative, 1945 annual report.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: Includes an index of four-color printing done by Save the Redwoods League, photo library index cards, and ceremonial pens and plaques.

did.unittitle: Index of four-color printing done by Save the Redwoods League.

scopecontent.p: Samples of print material ordered by Save the Redwoods League for distribution. Includes postcards, fliers, leaflets, pamphlets, brochures, bulletins, articles and membership certificates.

odd.p: Material originally assembled by Save the Redwoods League staff in two 3-ring binders. Material removed from binders and foldered by Bancroft Library staff.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by location, with miscellaneous at the end of the file.

scopecontent.p: 3x5 index cards that provide written information about photographs, bulk of which are of parks in Northern California. Cards are arranged by park or location. Information includes location, photo number, date taken (circa 1964-1987).

Framed pens used to sign legislation establishing Redwood National Park (Lyndon B. Johnson, 1968) and Headwaters Forest Reserve (Pete Wilson, 1998); an American Motors Conservation Award presented to the League in 1966; and a plaque presented by the California Department of Forestry commemorating the League's 75th anniversary in 1993.
